The mathematics side includes quiver theory and the McKay Correspondence which relates finite group representation theory to Lie algebras as well as crepant embeddings into K3 surface, while the "physics" aspect refers primarily to quantum gauge theories (at one end) where certain duality principles were proposed; other cases are related also by geometric algebra but have been more poorly explored: spinor field quantization and string/brane construction for example - despite these being a vast number of known results from 80s-90's work such an exploration is relatively new thanks entirely too some efforts already undertaken around recent years including this paper here!
source_text: The ubiquitous ADE classification has induced many proposals of often mysterious correspondences both in mathematics and physics. The mathematics side includes quiver theory and the McKay Correspondence which relates finite group representation theory to Lie algebras as well as crepant resolutions of Gorenstein singularities. On the physics side, we have the graph-theoretic classification of the modular invariants of WZW models, as well as the relation between the string theory nonlinear $\sigma$-models and Landau-Ginzburg orbifolds. We here propose a unification scheme which naturally incorporates all these correspondences of the ADE type in two complex dimensions. An intricate web of inter-relations is constructed, providing a possible guideline to establish new directions of research or alternate pathways to the standing problems in higher dimensions.

prompt: We show that it is possible to construct observables to test the existence of new physics in a model independent way for the $D^0\rightarrow VV$ modes using a time-dependent analysis of the neutral $D$ meson.
text: We show that it is possible to construct observables to test the existence of new physics in a model independent way for the $D^0\rightarrow VV$ modes using a time-dependent analysis of the neutral $D$ meson. We also discuss its application, with and without assuming chiral unitarity at the quark level. Finally we argue how such measurements can be performed experimentally as described by our theory on different mass scales depending from those which are assumed during theoretical computations. In particular this implies important extensions of some well-known results related directly or indirectly through experiments involving $\bar b_b$, $(c_c)^3 c_\rho/\sqrt{S_{nn}}(1-\delta)$ data: both allow access via
source_text: We show that it is possible to construct observables to test the existence of new physics in a model independent way for the $D^0\rightarrow VV$ modes using a time-dependent analysis of the neutral $D$ meson. We show that it is possible to identify whether the NP is due to decay, mixing or a combination of both. We also provide numerical estimates for the polarization amplitudes for the $D^0\rightarrow\overline{K^{*0}}\rho^0$ mode and show that our analysis is consistent with the present data.

prompt: In this article, we investigate the regularity for certain elliptic systems without a $L^2$-antisymmetric structure. As applications, we prove some $\epsilon$-regularity theorems for weakly harmonic maps from the
text: In this article, we investigate the regularity for certain elliptic systems without a $L^2$-antisymmetric structure. As applications, we prove some $\epsilon$-regularity theorems for weakly harmonic maps from the unit disc to Euclidean space and show that these maps are not smooth in general case (in particular they do not satisfy the maximal modulus principle). We also consider another class of nonlinear equations with no local symmetry and obtain similar results. Our main tools consist on an approximation scheme by means of the Riesz potential which allows us to get sharp inequalities under suitable assumptions on the function defining the map; furthermore it is useful when there exists a lower bound for all points where the function takes values. Finally,
source_text:

As applications, we prove some $\epsilon$-regularity theorems for weakly harmonic maps from the unit ball $B= B(m) \subset \mathbb{R}^m $ $(m\geq2)$ into certain pseudo-Riemannian manifolds: standard stationary Lorentzian manifolds, pseudospheres $\mathbb{S}^n_
